Well to those who complain about "10 seconds not being long enough to explain anything," I completely agree with the statement, you cannot get a thorough explanation on something like microwaves in ten seconds like the wave of a magic wand, but I will also disagree with the trend that MP deserves all this criticism, as the purpose of these videos isn't as much to explain, as much as it is to get viewer feedback for his next full length topic.  I don't understand why even regular fans are so mad, it's an experiment to create interactivity with the fan-base and let them have a vote for his next fleshed out topic.  There's no problem with that, if you want the thorough explanation on microwaves because the 10 second video has, done something along the lines of piquing your interest, or you think more people should learn about Time Dilation, when why not vote for it like the experiment intends and you can feel good that your input has an effect on the education on the activity of the channel and the education of yourself and others?

I think the format is a great idea, but I mean the entire thing: make a few weeks of 10 second clips, have a poll, and then make longer videos of the top 3 or 4 recommendations. I dunno, I mean, the numbers are variable, but you get what I mean. It also kills off some simpler topics (i.e. we don't need a 4 minute video explaining the tides, 10 seconds does fine). That would allow you to make longer videos on things that actually need a more nuanced explanation (i.e. your video on the multiverse, etc.)

While I do think that it is nice to try and change things up and add some spice to minutephysics, I personally don't agree with using 10 second videos as a poll to decide which full minute videos to create. This insinuates that every single 10 second video is technically capable of being made into a full one, so why not do just that? I would have watched every one, and I believe it is worth your time to create all those full videos without going through a voting process. This is your channel, and you shouldn't have to check with the audience before creating a video; just do what you enjoy and think is interesting to teach others. I don't mean in any way to ignore feedback, but I find these 10 second-ers to be frivolous. No offense of course, MP is awesome and I only want you to create more amazing stuff.

While the ten second physics videos have not been enough to explain some of these concepts to the audience (just look at the responses), they have been enough to start the conversation. In the comment sections of each of the videos one can read discussions had by people (some with more knowledge on the subject, some with less) about the concept.
In this way, I feel these videos have had a greater (or perhaps simply a 'different') community benefit than the regular videos. However, to make these discussions more beneficial than they have been, an end-cap video on the subject would need to be made to root out misconceptions and fill in the gaps.

Because of this, I support this methodology you have taken up and will cast my vote when the time comes. Thanks for the videos.

Concision is admirable, brevity for the sake of brevity, is not.
I would focus on finding topics/aspects where you can formulate a brilliantly concise and insightful explanation. How long it takes is a distant second. No pun intended.
As I believe Einstein said, make it as simple as possible but no simpler.

Say the microwave video. It was essentially void of information, only if you already knew the topic could you tell that you understood from the drawing that microwaves are EM radiation like light with different wavelength.
The explanation of light deserves far more than a 10 second layman's cartoon. As short as possible in the interest of efficacy but no shorter than the significant aspects are conveyed.
Don't stress on time, focus on information quality.
I would maybe talk about how the size of MW limits resolving power so you couldn't image everyday objects with it (diffraction limit etc). How it can't go through chickenmesh. I'd talk about how it's made (electro magnetic) meaning exactly the condition that starts it. I'd talk about typical uses like radar and how it goes through the atmosphere. How metal reflects and plastic is transparent. Why a fork arcs in a MW oven. Why it only heats some things. And maybe if you feel courageous, casually throw in that 'some claim that megawatt tracking radar microwaves can disrupt the propulsive field of some UFOs and that's how Roswell happened. Do it quickly and casually at the end, that way the vogon scientists wont have time to throw a hissyfit over something that's too big for the little minds to handle.
Because yes, there is some indication that UFOs aka ET ships use standing microwave constellations on the hull surface to invoke the funky physics they use. And that indeed this finely tuned field can be disrupted and the resonant coupling be lost and they fall down.
What few have thought about is that Roswell New Mexico was home to the only nuclear bomb carrying base in the world at the time of 1947 and that New Mexico had 3 experimental high power radars to guard the airspace around that base.
The roswell downing was thus accidental. At least 2 other ET craft were downed in 47 and 48, presumably the same way. It was discovered that radar can disrupt the propulsion. A very unexpected frailty but with the wonderful quality of making sense once discovered.
Weakminded scientists (basically all of them) don't like to think about the UFO phenomenon but isn't it interesting that our scifi has stupid rocket planes that fly like planes in space and make sound while the supposedly crazy hundreds of millions of people around the world speak of craft that are silent, do explosive accelerations and have featureless smooth metallic hulls with rotational symmetry that reeks of being dictated by field geometry...  not unlike a magnetic coil.
Not that there are many stars of considerable age or anything. Surely ET couldn't be real...  Impossiburu!
While most physicists are feeble minded when it comes to controversy, secretly, subconsciously, many are fascinated by the topic. Michiu Kaku has recently come around to cowardly admitting that UFOs are probably real ET ships.
